newsitem.title: UK: European bonds bounce back up but mood strained.
newsitem.headline: European bonds bounce back up but mood strained.

text.p: European bonds bounced higher in early trade on Friday, after stumbling lower in the previous session on speculation that U.S. interest rates would soon be moving up, analysts said.
Remarks from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on Thursday about the need to act pre-emptively to fight inflation lashed markets already fretting over U.S. rates policy, they said.
"The key thing is that T-bonds recovered a bit from when we went home last night," said Karl Haeling, head of futures and options for Germany at DMG Futures & Options in Frankfurt.
"Against that backdrop we've got a very oversold market and we're coming into the weekend so you've got some internal dynamics pushing for a little bit of correction," he said.
At 0852 GMT, June Bund futures on LIFFE were quoted at 100.12, up 44 basis points from Thursday, June gilts were up 13/32 at 109-11, and June BTP futures were up 0.64 at 125.75.
On the MATIF in Paris, June notionnel futures were up 0.64 at 127.96 from Thursday while June T-bond futures were up 6/32 at 108-27 in automated trade.
The Federal Reserve holds its Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday and analysts said trade would be strained until then.

"We're definitely going to be edgy," Haeling said. "Maybe we could have another 3/4 point rally on the upside on the Bunds but it's going to be very difficult to get above the 101.00-30 area," he said, citing this week's highs as technical resistance.

"We've done good damage to the charts but most importantly we've done big damage to psychology here," he said. "With the price action since Monday we've had people completely change their whole outlook (on U.S. rates)."

Adam Chester, international bond strategist at Yamaichi International Europe added, "Every man and his dog is now looking for a rate increase. If the Fed weren't to go next week now I think they would face a credibility problem. I think Greenspan and all the other members have marked the market's card with regard to a rate hike now."
